review_title: Great for Building Diverse Skillset, Bad for Work-Life Balance
pros: - great for building a skillset that will benefit you in different, higher-paying industries -good benefits
cons: - don't expect career growth internally. disparate promotion policies & favoritism exhibited in how closely to adhere to supposed promotion policies. -compensation is not sufficient for amount of hours/weekend work -I encountered discriminatory behavior on the part of department leadership while working here -- "boys' club" atmosphere , exhibited particularly by some members of leadership, although they claim to uphold DEI values -although there's good vacation time, I encountered restrictions around using that time (have to be on campus for events throughout the summer, travel events, open houses, etc. which happen practically every week during most of the year)

pros: Mission driven school that cares a lot about students
cons: Salary does not keep up with inflation

job_title: Prospect Research Officer in Lutherville Timonium, MD
pros: Loyola has a healthy work atmosphere. It feels like a family and our goal is to help each other for the greater good of the university.
cons: Every job comes with challenges. Just come ready to tackle whatever workload is given to you.

pros: The community feeling is evident. People are professional and everyone is open to working together. Students are respectful. Leadership has been around for a long time, which means that the historic values and culture of Loyola remain in place. Pay is low but the 9% 403b match, 20 days of vacation (for exempt employees; 10 for non exempt), 19 holidays, and tuition remission make up for it.
cons: Loyola is a bit stuck in the past and closed off from those outside the community. The downside of leadership having been there a long time means that no major changes (which many think are needed) will be made anytime soon. HR cannot keep up with basic personnel tasks, let alone work on employee engagement and pay equity.

job_title: Non Tenure Track Faculty in Baltimore, MD
pros: The students, staff, and some of the faculty
cons: Pay is very low in Loyola School of Arts and Sciences - those working in the same faculty position within Sellinger School of Business make more, most of the diverse faculty and staff are vulnerable to pay cuts and no raises, faculty and staff have no voice in regards to pay, staff has a high turnover rate, and departments are underfunded.

review_title: The community is wonderful, but the leadership is lacking
pros:
Family friendly workplace 
4 weeks paid vacation 
If you are starting your career, there are opportunities to grow within the organization.
cons:
- There is a lack of leadership. 
- Due to the lack of leadership, the current employees tend to be people who either can’t find jobs somewhere else or stay because they can coast without working too hard. So many of the hard working employees have left over frustrations with lack of leadership. 
- If you are not a white man, be prepared to be treated differently and have leadership and HR act shocked when you bring it to their attention.

pros: I was able to conduct my own original research as an undergraduate through the fellowship alongside 2 advisors. Fellowship was flexible.
cons: I really don't have any cons. Much of the fellowship was set up so I could hit deadlines and get help when I needed it.

review_title: A Poorly and Sometimes Abusively Run Place
pros: This is an institution that is dedicated to its mission, with people overly committed to ensuring it lives up to its ideals. The sense of community is wonderful, and people in general go above and beyond to serve each other and the student body. The organization relies on the generosity and sacrifice of its members, which is both good and bad. There is relatively good work-life balance, and the campus is an exceptionally pretty place to work. The students are the Crown Jewels of the place, and are the only reason so many of us continue to work there.
cons: The leadership of the organization is detached from the day to day concerns of members, views them with disdain and takes no interest in soliciting real feedback. There is no accountability for administrators, and senior leaders continue to enact policies that only apply to those below them, while they behave however they wish. My supervisor is passively abusive toward me, and micromanages and bullies me repeatedly. She has interfered with my ability to do my job, undermines me with colleagues, and in general has used her authority over me in duplicitous and harassing ways. There is no recourse because all of the senior leaders are friends, nepotism/favoritism runs rampant, and fear of retaliation is common. This is not a safe environment, and it does not tolerate dissent, particularly from those who are not white women, well at all. The organization is in the process of searching for a new president. It desperately needs better management, a clearer strategic direction, and a return to valuing its people. We are being taken advantage of under the guise of Jesuit ideals, and no one is listening.

pros: Super flexible and easy work
cons: I can’t think of any

pros: There are many talented and caring people at Loyola working the front lines of a difficult and more competitive environment than ever before. The campus is beautiful and a great place for better than average students to learn and become successful.
cons: Loyola is trying to be something that it is not—an elite, highly selective university. In the past they may have been, but their competitors have lapped them several times over. If they would just be comfortable with what/who they are, they may have better success.

job_title: Head Basketball Coach in Baltimore, MD
pros: location, campus life, benefits, environment

review_title: For students: Good if you can get work-study
pros: The Study, which is where peer tutors work, is a very nice environment. Peer tutors also have extremely flexible hours. The campus in general is very nice and each of the people I worked with were very nice. The fact that the Athletics department adheres very strictly to stringent procedures for tutoring their athletes shows a good amount of integrity.
cons: As an applicant to be a student the university, I was told there were always jobs available on campus. In fact very few of the jobs are open to students who do not have work-study.

review_title: They Love You!....If You're an Alum...
pros: Free Graduate Degree after one year of of employment.
cons:
Higher Administration loves you...if you're an Alum. They higher Alumni with zero to little experience, and it shows in the work the school produces.

There is also no room for advancement in your Career, as no one ever leaves.

Campus Police never report neighborhood crimes that happen on campus, let alone their own officers that were stealing from Student's Dorm Rooms.

I still have yet to be introduced to the President. I have worked at other Higher Ed Institutions where the last part of the interview is a sit down with the President, and the President even saying hello to you on your first day! I doubt Father Linnane even knows I exist!

Also, Board Members are allowed to belittle and trash talk Loyola Employees/Professors on Social Media, and still serve on the Board without any repercussions.

pros: The school is located in a beautiful neighborhood, which doesn't stop the snobbish campus police to give out parking tickets to every car park in those neighborhood. $85 a parking ticket? The streets belong to Baltimore CIty, and I pay Baltimore CIty taxes.
cons:
HR can't seem to get things right - your benefits account was supposed to be set up months ago, yet things always messed up, and they can't seem to remember which employee's case they need to work on even though you've been calling them for months. Incompetent or indifference? 

This has traditionally been an all-white university. It has made progress toward diversity over the years, but if you are not white, you know the difference. It's not hard to tell, even from the secretary.

review_title: Loved the Jesuit way but some fundamental red flags
pros: Loved the staff across campus, great co-workers all committed to helping students, great benefits if you were planning on being there for the long haul.
cons: The pay didn't reflect the cost of living.  As i was leaving, there were starting lay people off.    I thought the leadership became out of touch...especially at the executive level.  HR is probably the worst out of the universities i have worked at.  The diversity piece was a huge red flag. I know this was a predominately white school but I think there is a great opportunity to connect a little more with the community.

pros: time off and holidays. also depending on where you work sometimes but the coworkers are great. also free school for you and your kids is a huge plus for this job here.
cons: everyone is treated different.  the annual job reviews are all different by different people and are not standard across the board.  treatment by facilities management is very bad and the attitude there is toxic.  plainly in my opinion one of the most dishonest and disrespectful places i have ever worked at.

review_title: Cura personalis-less. A review from a 10+ year veteran and former student.
pros: Good community. Good benefits. Good people in the trenches. Used to be a special place to be.
cons: Old leadership has been chased out and culture changing for the worst. Mid-level management completely clueless and concerned only with self-preservation. Politics are sickening. I had 5 bosses in the last 5 years. Ultimately, I was fired without severance weeks before having a new baby and over the phone after 10+ years of service. What does that tell you about their leadership??

review_title: Great place to work in higher ed around a greater mission
job_title: Student Development Professional in Baltimore, MD
pros: Jesuit ideals go into many parts of the work you can do with students, and give you a great springboard for conversations around ethics and purpose.
cons: Not many to consider.  It was a great place to work for many years before moving away from the area.  If pressed, the budget is highly dependent on tuition dollars as the endowment is not as strong as it could be for this level of school.  So some student development budget cuts have been necessary lately from what I'm hearing.

pros: You truly become part of a community.  GREAT benefits.  If you get involved with the university (not just as a job) but truly INVOLVED (Staff Council, Chapel Choir, etc...) you can see how your job really helps the university on an every day basis.
cons: Getting stuck at a "Pay Rate" as a staff member can be disheartening.  "Other duties as assigned" as staff member is a lot of your job - but if you ask the right questions going in, you'll know that all upfront.

review_title: Great place to work as a grad student
pros: I worked here for three years part time while I was in grad school. Great place to work, my boss was great and really helped me build my skills to later get a job after I graduated. Working on campus gives you access to all on campus facilities. Very easy to balance school and a graduate assistantship assuming that you have a good boss.
cons: Pay for graduate assistants is quite low compared to other jobs I could have gotten outside of the university.  Comes with the typical politics that come with working at a university.

job_title: Student Escort Driver/Dispatcher Student Supervisort in Baltimore, MD
pros: The staff was fantastic -- I loved working with the police department on campus. The job wasn't too intensive for any of the employees.
cons: Payroll was often a misery -- it is a student position so things are naturally difficult. Sometimes it would take a month to get a pay check. But I was always payed in full

job_title: Assistant Director of Student Life in Baltimore, MD
pros: Everyone is very collegial and willing truly there for the students. Benefits are pretty good, and the students are great.
cons: Compensation increases don't come regularly. HR is not the best at what they do, and the higher management doesn't take the time to get to know employees.

pros: Rewarding experience tutoring students, choose your own schedule, very flexible. Tutor coordinator is nice and helpful.
cons: Students sometimes do not show up, when this happens you only get paid for 15 minutes of the session (around 2 dollars). Don't always get a certain amount of hours a week.

job_title: FAC Building Supervisor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Provided a lot of responsibility for a student employee.  Clear duties, protocols, and systems.
cons: The boss was a pain at times and would give you pointless jobs if you seemed too free.  The pay was terrible for student hires.

pros: Being employed at Loyola for ten years now is a big deal. I truly enjoy the atmosphere here and appreciate all of the benefits offered. I am allotted ample PTO, no weekends or evenings, and the healthcare package is very affordable.
cons: I wish I could get off at 4 pm on Fridays.

review_title: Great place to find caring atmosphere where students' and employees' whole persons are important.
